description: National Fire Alarm and Signaling Code requirements

questions.question: What NFPA standard is the National Fire Alarm and Signaling Code?
questions.explanation: NFPA 72 is the National Fire Alarm and Signaling Code, covering installation, testing, and maintenance of fire alarm and emergency communication systems.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a fire alarm control panel (FACP)?
options: To receive signals from initiating devices and activate notification appliances
questions.explanation: The FACP is the brain of the fire alarm system. It receives signals from initiating devices, processes them, and activates notification appliances and other outputs.

questions.question: What is an initiating device?
options: A device that starts the fire alarm panel
A device that detects fire or manually activates an alarm
questions.explanation: Initiating devices include smoke detectors, heat detectors, manual pull stations, and waterflow switches that detect fire conditions or allow manual alarm activation.

questions.question: What is a notification appliance?
options: A device that alerts occupants (horns, strobes, speakers)
questions.explanation: Notification appliances alert building occupants to fire conditions. They include audible devices (horns, bells, speakers) and visible devices (strobes).

questions.question: How often must fire alarm systems be tested per NFPA 72?
options: Annually, with some devices more frequently
questions.explanation: NFPA 72 Chapter 14 requires annual testing of most devices, with some components (batteries, generators) tested more frequently (monthly or semi-annually).

questions.question: What is the minimum sound level for audible notification appliances in a sleeping area?
questions.explanation: In sleeping areas, audible notification appliances must produce at least 75 dB at the pillow level or 15 dB above ambient sound, whichever is greater.

questions.question: What color must manual fire alarm pull stations be?
questions.explanation: Manual fire alarm pull stations must be red to be readily identifiable as fire alarm devices.

questions.question: What is the maximum mounting height for manual pull stations (ADA compliant)?
questions.explanation: Manual pull stations must be mounted between 42 and 48 inches above the floor to be accessible per ADA requirements.

questions.question: What is the standard temporal pattern for fire alarm signals?
questions.explanation: The standard fire alarm evacuation signal is the temporal-3 pattern: three pulses ON, then OFF, repeated. This distinguishes fire alarms from other signals.

questions.question: What secondary power source is required for fire alarm systems?
questions.explanation: Fire alarm systems require secondary power (typically batteries) that can operate the system for 24 hours in standby plus 5 minutes of alarm (or 15 minutes for voice systems).

questions.question: What is the maximum spacing for spot-type smoke detectors on smooth ceilings?
questions.explanation: Spot-type smoke detectors have a nominal spacing of 30 feet on smooth ceilings. This may be reduced based on ceiling height, beam depth, or other factors.

questions.question: How does ceiling height affect smoke detector spacing?
options: Spacing decreases as ceiling height increases beyond 10 feet
questions.explanation: As ceiling height increases beyond 10 feet, smoke detector spacing must be reduced per NFPA 72 tables to account for smoke stratification and dilution.

questions.question: What is the supervision requirement for fire alarm circuit wiring?
options: All circuits must be supervised for opens, grounds, and shorts
questions.explanation: NFPA 72 requires that all fire alarm circuits be electrically supervised for opens, grounds, and shorts to ensure system integrity.

questions.question: What is a Class A circuit configuration?
options: Loop configuration that survives a single open
questions.explanation: Class A circuits use a loop configuration where wiring returns to the panel. A single open will not prevent device operation since signals can reach from either direction.

questions.question: What is the difference between Class B and Class A notification circuits?
options: Class A provides circuit fault tolerance; Class B does not
Class A is for horns only
questions.explanation: Class A circuits continue operating devices on both sides of a single open fault. Class B circuits lose devices beyond the fault point.

questions.question: What is required when a fire alarm system is connected to a monitoring station?
options: Two communication paths or single path with specific reliability
questions.explanation: Monitoring station connections may require redundant communication paths or single paths meeting specific reliability criteria per NFPA 72 requirements.

questions.question: What is the minimum candela rating for visible notification appliances in corridors?
questions.explanation: Visible notification appliances in corridors (up to 20 feet wide) require minimum 15 cd. Larger spaces require higher intensities based on room dimensions.

questions.question: How far from a wall corner must a smoke detector be mounted?
questions.explanation: Smoke detectors on ceilings must be at least 4 feet from walls in rooms with corners, as dead air spaces near walls can prevent smoke detection.

questions.question: What documentation must be provided upon completion of fire alarm installation?
options: Record of completion (as-built drawings, equipment list, test records)
questions.explanation: NFPA 72 requires a Record of Completion including as-built drawings, device list, sequence of operation, and acceptance test documentation.

questions.question: What type of detector is required in elevator machine rooms?
options: Both smoke and heat detectors typically
questions.explanation: Elevator machine rooms typically require both smoke detectors (for Phase I recall) and heat detectors (for shunt trip). Requirements vary by code.

questions.question: What is the sensitivity range for smoke detectors?
questions.explanation: Listed smoke detectors must operate between approximately 0.5% and 4.0% per foot obscuration. Sensitivity testing ensures detectors remain in this range.

questions.question: What is the maximum distance from an exit to a manual pull station?
options: Within 5 feet of exit travel path
questions.explanation: Manual pull stations must be located within 5 feet of each exit doorway on the egress side to be accessible during evacuation.

questions.question: What is the formula for calculating the number of notification appliances for visible coverage?
options: Based on manufacturer's polar distribution patterns
questions.explanation: NFPA 72 Table 18.5.4.3.1 provides candela ratings based on room dimensions. Placement is determined by the table and manufacturer polar distribution data.

questions.question: For a 40 foot × 50 foot room, what candela rating is required for wall-mounted visible appliances?
questions.explanation: Using NFPA 72 Table 18.5.4.3.1(a), a room 40' × 50' with one wall-mounted appliance requires 185 cd minimum.

questions.question: What is the smoke detector sensitivity test frequency per NFPA 72?
options: Within 1 year of installation, then every other year
questions.explanation: Smoke detector sensitivity must be tested within 1 year of installation, then every alternate year thereafter. Detectors outside the listed range must be replaced or cleaned/recalibrated.

questions.question: What is the voltage drop limit for fire alarm notification appliance circuits?
questions.explanation: Voltage drop must be calculated to ensure notification appliances receive adequate voltage per manufacturer's specifications, typically ensuring 85% of rated voltage minimum.

questions.question: When is duct smoke detection required?
options: Systems over 2000 CFM per building/fire code
questions.explanation: Duct smoke detection is required by mechanical and building codes (typically over 2000 CFM). NFPA 72 provides installation requirements when required by other codes.

questions.question: What is the maximum resistance allowed for a single ground fault on a fire alarm circuit?
options: Ground faults must be detected regardless of resistance
questions.explanation: Fire alarm circuits must be free of ground faults. Any ground fault must be indicated as a trouble condition. The detection sensitivity varies by system design.

questions.question: What calculation method determines battery capacity for fire alarm systems?
options: Standby load × hours + alarm load × alarm duration
questions.explanation: Battery sizing: (Standby current × standby hours) + (Alarm current × alarm duration in hours). Result is multiplied by 1.2 safety factor.

questions.question: What is the pathway survivability requirement for emergency voice systems in high-rise buildings?
questions.explanation: High-rise buildings typically require Level 2 or Level 3 pathway survivability (2-hour rated enclosure or construction) for emergency voice/alarm communication systems.
